Cat two files
posttext: i want to cat two files together.  i know i can do it with shell(), but i am trying to be good and use run.prog for future support.  i understand that run.prog doesn't like ">" in the argument section.  how do i get around this?e = run.prog("cat", tmp_file & ".header " &tmp_file & ".sort > " &f.in.dir & "/" & f.in.name, rp_wait)the above is what i have tried, but it doesn't seem to work.cheers,-dennis =|=|= this might work:cmd = "cat " & tmpfile & ".header" & tmpfile &".sort > " & f.in.dir & "/" & f.in.namee=run.prog("csh",cmd,rp_wait)i use something like this.mark =|=|= mark,tried it a few ways based on your suggestion:1) command = ksh but leave args to be built in run.prog command2) new variable to build argument list but stil call command = cat in run.prog3) new variable for args and also put 'cat' in the args and call command = ksh.none of the three work.for the time being, i have resorted to shell().thanks for the try.cheers,-dennis =|=|= dennis,i had the similar issue as you but i prefer not to use cat in case of over writing existing file, or write access to certain directories etc.hence, i made a generic function to handle it in baan tools. its simple and os independent.function extern	long	append.file(string source(256), string	target(256)){dllusageappend source file to a target file.return : 0=file handling errors, or source = target; 1=successenddllusagelong	fp1, fp2string	buffer(1024)if source = target thenreturn(0)endiffp1 = seq.open(source, "r")fp2 = seq.open(target, "a")if fp1 < 0 or fp2 < 0 thenmess("zmadms0010", 1)		|* file handling errorsreturn(0)endifwhile not seq.gets(buffer, 1024, fp1)e = seq.puts(buffer, fp2)endwhilee = seq.close(fp1)e = seq.close(fp2)return(1)} =|=|= i made a small discovery today that, while not documented as such, run.prog (http://www.baanboard.com/programmers_manual_baanerp_help_functions_starting_and_stopping_programs_run_baan_prog_run_prog) will accept the extra three parameters of stdin, stdout & stderr just like run.baan.prog (http://www.baanboard.com/programmers_manual_baanerp_help_functions_starting_and_stopping_programs_run_baan_prog_run_prog) does.therefore, the above command would probably be:e = run.prog("cat",tmp_file & ".header " & tmp_file & ".sort ",rp_wait,"",f.in.dir & "/" & f.in.name,"")cheers,-dennis
